body: • An article about the Tesla Model 3 electric car said “driving 200 miles will use 65 kW of electricity. That’s around £6.50 during the day if you are on one of the UK’s cheapest tariffs (10p/kW), or £11 on a standard tariff (around 17p/kW).” All the references to kilowatts should have been to kilowatt-hours. Kilowatts are units of power, and kilowatt-hours are units of energy. A kilowatt-hour is a unit of energy equivalent to one kilowatt of power expended for one hour (At ‘just’ £25,000, is this the electric car that means you’re driving a bargain?, 7 May, page 41). • A piece celebrating Leicester City’s Premier League victory went on to say that there were five good reasons why England might not win the European Championship this summer – Germany, Spain, Italy, France and Holland. Holland should not have been included in that list: the Dutch national team failed to qualify for Euro 2016 (So we’re all Foxes now? I’ve been one for 65 years, 7 May, page 1). • Hillary Clinton’s first name was misspelled as Hilary in an article about the US election (Trump’s policies may be incoherent but the fragile US economy gives him a real chance, 9 May, page 21). • Other recently corrected articles include: Unicef calls for 300 child refugees to be let into UK to attend school
